data.title: Converter script doesn't specify text file encoding
data.body:
While running the convert script, [util.fslike.path](https://github.com/SFTtech/openage/blob/0f895d3dbb0058d710dd8f0a839c3677b9b7edbe/openage/util/fslike/path.py#L100-L104) doesn't specify text file encoding nor give any mean to specify one. This could lead to some unicode encoding/decoding error at some point.

The default encoding used by [TextIOWrapper](https://docs.python.org/3/library/io.html#io.TextIOWrapper) is `locale.getpreferredencoding(False)` and depending on the system this doesn't necessarily return 'utf-8' ( ;o )

To reproduce the problem simply change the system locale (change the `LANG` environment variable on Linux systems) to another locale (try `ANSIX3.4-1968`) before the convert script runs. Hopefully, the script should raise an `UnicodeEncodingError` exception at some point while trying to encode a Python unicode string...

If we know the encoding of the our files, whether we are reading or writing them, we should specify that encoding explicitly instead of relying on some [weird default system encoding](http://askubuntu.com/questions/581458/how-to-configure-locales-to-unicode-in-a-docker-ubuntu-14-04-container).

data.title: Check for compiler's thread_local support
data.body:
As apple is still failing horribly with thread local storage, we should abort the build as soon as possible.

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/28094794/why-does-apple-clang-disallow-c11-thread-local-when-official-clang-supports

Something like this will detect it at configure stage:

``` cmake
include(CheckCXXSourceCompiles)
check_cxx_source_compiles("thread_local int i = 0; int main() { return i; }" HAVE_COMPILER_TLS)
if(NOT HAVE_COMPILER_TLS)
    message(FATAL_ERROR "Your compiler sucks and doesn't support thread_local storage.")
endif()
```

data.title: Out of Source Builds
data.body:
- python sources in openage folder are replicated in build dir.
- cpp, html, and cython modules are now generated in build dir
  and therefore keeps the source directory clean.
- pxd files are generated in the build dir.
- removed os-dependent functionality like `symlinks` and `find`.
- replaced add_cython_modules with better api `add_cython_module`.
- with these changes, individual cython modules depend on only their
  source files. Therefore, changes to cython module source files
  will trigger build of only dependent targets. Also, removed the
  need to explicitly specify pxd files through `add_pxds`.
- in general, simplified the build system by removing the custom targets
  compilepy, inplacemodules, cleanpxdgen, cythonize, cleancython.
- As CMake is now responsible for managing timestamps of pxd files
  and corresponding source files, pxdgen is now simpler.
- fixed devmode detection.

Fixes #398 , #391 

This completes the changes required for "fully" out-of-source builds. The only files generated in source tree are `codegen` files. These files are not dependent on any configuration and therefore acceptable (for now).

Also removed the generation of configuration dependent files like `inplace_module_list` in configuration independent dir `bin/py/`. Therefore, the project can now be built using multi config cmake generators (Tested with Xcode).

data.title: Better out-of-source build python support
data.body:
We should consider boosting the buildsystem with ideas from:

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13959434/cmake-out-of-source-build-python-files

Basically:
- Don't rely on the source folder at all when running
- Achieve this by symlinking/copying into build directory
- This makes `make install` easier to implement and understand as the runimage already is present in the binary dir (although symlinks have to be fixed then)

data.title: Unified ressource manager
data.body:
To avoid having to implement file loading again and again, we should have a file and resource manager that all other subsystems use to access data files.

This new subsystem should be aware of the filesystem union already implemented in python to overlay mod packs. For performance reasons, it's probably not a good idea calling to the existing python code for that, but I'm not sure.

Anyway, this manager is for loading and saving `.docx`, `.nyan`, `.opus`, shaders, savegames, fonts and everything else that interacts with files in any way.

This basically is the asset manager.

data.title: Fix devmode detection by not installing __pycache__/devmode.pyc

milestone.title: Next release
milestone.description: We have a working Qt GUI and many more features! This release is soooo overdue...

data.body:
To detect if we're running in the repo or as installed program in `/usr` or whatever,
we test if the devmode python module can be imported.

The `devmode.py` file is not installed to the installation directory. That way, when running as installed program, the module can't be imported.

The problem now is that the buildsystem converts all python code to compiled `.pyc` files.
The `devmode.py` is not installed, but the `devmode.pyc` file is.

Python does import the `pyc` file even though the `.py` file is missing.

=> Prevent the buildsystem to install corresponding `pyc` files to not-installed `py` files.

data.title: Include -L<dir> flag for linking against python
data.body:
This is a proposed fix for issue #379, in which the python library could not be found by the linker. Now we are grabbing the correct library directory using distutils, and also generating the library name the same way as the python-config tool. These are then given to the linker with -L and -l, respectively.

In the future, we should use the python-config tool to grab all ldflags and cflags. I currently don't use the python-config tool because it can include many flags (e.g, extra libraries) that we simply aren't ready to incorporate yet, and therefore would require much filtering. Since this is not currently a problem, it's a feature, not a bug.

I tested the fix on:

Mac OS X Yosemite 10.10.4 (14E46)
Python 3.4 installed with brew install python3
Using g++ version 5.2.0

and

Ubuntu 14.0.4-3
Python 3.4 installed with apt-get
Using both g++ version 4.9.2, and clang++ version 3.6.0

data.title: Python 3.4 library not found on Mac OS X.
data.body:
**System setup:**
Mac OS X Yosemite 10.10.4 (14E46)
Python 3.4 installed with `brew install python3`
Using g++ version 5.2.0

**The symptom:** When building the "run" executable, the linker fails with error `ld: library not found for -lpython3.4`

My investigation reveals the following:

**The superficial cause:** Python libraries are not copied to system library directories in Mac installs. And no `-Lpath` compiler option is used for compiling "run".

**The root cause:** The distutils python package is currently being erroneously used to grab the C/C++ library information. In fact, distutils is currently returning the location of libraries to _import_ into python scripts. It's a coincidence that the real library name has the same name `python3.4`. Therefore, since it wasn't designed for it, distutils can't be used to the find the library's location...

**Recommendation:** We use the python configuration tool to tell us the exact linker arguments instead: (e.g., with `python$(VERSION)-config --ldflags`). While we are at it, we could grab the cflags with `--cflags` as well. This way we are always using the appropriate flags that the Python package builders meant for us to use when linking against Python. 

**Drawbacks:** This solution works with the Homebrew Python 3.4 installation on Mac OS X. However, I have observed the ldflags can sometimes contain extra -lfile libs that are not currently included in our build system, which can then lead to a similar error. This was observed with the MacPorts installation.
